title: Jeremiah Chapter 47 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 47 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 47 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 47.

questions.question: Who received the word of the LORD against the Philistines?
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah the prophet
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:1 states that the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah the prophet against the Philistines.

questions.question: Before what event did the word against the Philistines come to Jeremiah?
questions.correctAnswer: Before Pharaoh smote Gaza
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:1 mentions the word of the LORD against the Philistines came before Pharaoh smote Gaza.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 47:2, where do the waters rise up from?
questions.correctAnswer: Out of the north
questions.explanation: Verse 2 declares that waters rise up out of the north as an overflowing flood.

questions.question: What will the inhabitants of the land do when the waters overflow, according to Jeremiah 47:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Cry and howl
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:2 says men shall cry and all inhabitants shall howl when the flood overflows the land.

questions.question: What sound is described in Jeremiah 47:3 that causes fathers not to look back to their children?
questions.correctAnswer: Stamping of hoofs of horses
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:3 mentions the noise of stamping hoofs of strong horses, chariots rushing, and rumbling wheels.

questions.question: What will happen to the Philistines on the day that cometh, according to Jeremiah 47:4?
questions.correctAnswer: They will be spoiled
questions.explanation: Verse 4 says the day comes to spoil all the Philistines and cut off helpers from Tyrus and Zidon.

questions.question: Which country is mentioned as the remnant from which the Philistines come?
questions.correctAnswer: Caphtor
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:4 states the Philistines are the remnant of the country of Caphtor.

questions.question: What condition is said to have come upon Gaza in Jeremiah 47:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Baldness
questions.explanation: Verse 5 declares baldness is come upon Gaza.

questions.question: Which city is cut off along with the remnant of their valley, according to Jeremiah 47:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Ashkelon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:5 states Ashkelon is cut off with the remnant of their valley.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 47:6, what is the LORD's sword told to do?
options: Put up itself into its scabbard and rest
questions.correctAnswer: Put up itself into its scabbard and rest
questions.explanation: Verse 6 asks the sword of the LORD to be quiet, rest, and be still by putting itself into its scabbard.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 47:3 describes the rumbling of wheels as part of the noise that causes fathers not to look back.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:3 mentions the rumbling of wheels along with horses and chariots as the noise causing fear.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 47:4, the LORD will help the Philistines by sending helpers from Tyrus and Zidon.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:4 says the LORD will cut off every helper that remaineth from Tyrus and Zidon, not help the Philistines.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 47:7 states that the sword of the LORD has been appointed against Ashkelon and the sea shore.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 7 confirms the LORD has given a charge against Ashkelon and the sea shore, appointing the sword.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 47:2: 'Behold, waters rise up out of the ______, and shall be an overflowing flood.'
questions.correctAnswer: north
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:2 says waters rise up out of the north as an overflowing flood.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 47:5: 'Baldness is come upon ______; Ashkelon is cut off with the remnant of their valley.'
questions.correctAnswer: Gaza
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:5 states baldness has come upon Gaza.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 47 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 47 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Jeremiah 47:2, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in overwhelming circumstances?
options: God’s judgment is certain but He is sovereign over all events
Trials are random and without purpose
We should rely only on our own strength to overcome difficulties
God abandons those who face hardships
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment is certain but He is sovereign over all events
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:2 describes an overflowing flood from the north symbolizing God’s judgment. This shows God’s control over events, reminding believers to trust His sovereignty during trials.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 47:3 teach us about the importance of faith and courage when facing fearful situations?
options: We should not look back or be weakened by fear but trust God’s plan
Fear is a sign of weak faith and must be ignored
We must rely on others to protect us at all times
questions.correctAnswer: We should not look back or be weakened by fear but trust God’s plan
questions.explanation: Verse 3 shows fathers not looking back to their children due to feebleness, symbolizing that believers should stand firm and courageous, trusting God’s judgment and plan.

questions.question: What practical lesson about obedience to God’s Word can be drawn from Jeremiah 47:4 regarding consequences for nations or individuals?
options: Disobedience leads to spoil and removal of help, so obeying God is crucial
God does not punish nations or individuals
Consequences are only for others, not for believers
Obedience is optional and without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience leads to spoil and removal of help, so obeying God is crucial
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:4 mentions the day coming to spoil the Philistines and cut off helpers, illustrating that disobedience to God leads to consequences, encouraging obedience.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with impatience in prayer. Based on Jeremiah 47:6, what biblical truth about waiting on God would you share?
options: God’s timing is perfect; even the 'sword of the LORD' must eventually rest
We should demand immediate answers from God
God never pauses in His actions
questions.correctAnswer: God’s timing is perfect; even the 'sword of the LORD' must eventually rest
questions.explanation: Verse 6 asks how long the sword of the LORD will rest, implying God acts in His perfect timing, teaching believers to be patient and trust His timing in prayer.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 47:5 illustrate the importance of repentance and humility in spiritual discipline?
options: The call to stop cutting oneself symbolizes a call to turn from futile acts and humble repentance
Physical suffering is the only way to please God
Self-harm is a necessary spiritual practice
Humility is not related to repentance
questions.correctAnswer: The call to stop cutting oneself symbolizes a call to turn from futile acts and humble repentance
questions.explanation: Verse 5 mentions cutting oneself and baldness, symbolic of mourning or despair, urging the people to stop and repent humbly rather than futile acts.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 47:7 teach about God’s sovereignty and faithfulness in fulfilling His promises?
options: God will fulfill His appointed plans against Ashkelon and the seashore
Promises are not guaranteed to be fulfilled
God has no control over nations
questions.correctAnswer: God will fulfill His appointed plans against Ashkelon and the seashore
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states that God has given a charge against Ashkelon and the seashore, showing His faithfulness to carry out His plans, encouraging believers to trust His promises.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged by witnessing injustice. Based on Jeremiah 47:1, what biblical truth about God’s justice would you share?
options: God’s word brings justice even when human actions seem unjust
questions.correctAnswer: God’s word brings justice even when human actions seem unjust
questions.explanation: Verse 1 introduces the word of the LORD against the Philistines, demonstrating that God’s justice will ultimately prevail over injustice.

questions.question: How does the imagery of horses, chariots, and wheels in Jeremiah 47:3 remind believers about perseverance through trials?
options: Trials may be powerful and noisy, but believers are to stand firm without turning back
One should flee from all difficulties
questions.correctAnswer: Trials may be powerful and noisy, but believers are to stand firm without turning back
questions.explanation: Verse 3’s imagery of powerful horses and chariots represents strong trials; believers are encouraged not to turn back but persevere in faith.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 47:4 teaches that God will remove support from those who oppose Him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:4 says God will cut off every helper from Tyrus and Zidon, showing He removes support from His enemies.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 47:6 encourages the sword of the LORD to remain active and never rest.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 6 asks how long the sword of the LORD will be quiet and calls it to rest, indicating that God’s judgment is active but will have a time to cease.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 47:2 describes the waters rising out of the _____ as an overflowing flood that will affect the land and its inhabitants.
questions.correctAnswer: north
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:2 states that waters rise up out of the north as an overflowing flood, symbolizing the coming judgment.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with anger and bitterness toward others. Based on Jeremiah 47:5, what biblical wisdom about self-control and repentance can you share?
options: Futile self-harm or despair will not solve problems; repentance and turning to God is needed
Bitterness is a sign of faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Futile self-harm or despair will not solve problems; repentance and turning to God is needed
questions.explanation: Verse 5’s mention of cutting oneself reflects despair; the passage encourages stopping such acts and turning to God with repentance.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 47:1 encourage believers to be faithful witnesses in challenging environments?
options: God calls prophets to speak His word even against powerful enemies
Believers should stay silent in the face of opposition
Only kings should proclaim God’s word
questions.correctAnswer: God calls prophets to speak His word even against powerful enemies
questions.explanation: Verse 1 shows Jeremiah speaking God’s word against the Philistines, demonstrating the call to witness faithfully regardless of opposition.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 47:4 teach about the importance of integrity and honesty in personal and communal life?
options: Losing helpers due to spoil warns that dishonesty and disobedience lead to ruin
Integrity is optional in difficult times
questions.correctAnswer: Losing helpers due to spoil warns that dishonesty and disobedience lead to ruin
questions.explanation: The verse shows that the Philistines’ downfall is linked to God’s judgment, implying that lack of integrity leads to ruin, teaching believers to live honestly.

questions.question: How can Jeremiah 47:7 inspire believers to have contentment and gratitude amid challenges?
options: Knowing God has appointed His plans gives confidence and peace amid uncertainty
Gratitude is not necessary in hardship
questions.correctAnswer: Knowing God has appointed His plans gives confidence and peace amid uncertainty
questions.explanation: Verse 7 affirms God’s appointed charge, encouraging believers to be content and grateful, trusting God’s sovereign control.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 47 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 47.

questions.question: What is the initial setting described in Jeremiah 47:1 for the prophecy against the Philistines?
options: At the time of King David
questions.correctAnswer: Before Pharaoh smote Gaza
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:1 explicitly states that the prophecy against the Philistines came before Pharaoh smote Gaza, establishing the historical and geopolitical context.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 47:2, the imagery of waters rising out of the north symbolizes what kind of event?
options: An overflowing flood that devastates the land
A peaceful blessing of rain and prosperity
A ritual cleansing by the priests
questions.correctAnswer: An overflowing flood that devastates the land
questions.explanation: Verse 2 uses flood imagery to symbolize a destructive invasion or judgment coming from the north that overwhelms the land and inhabitants.

questions.question: What does the sound of 'stamping of the hoofs' and 'rushing of his chariots' in Jeremiah 47:3 symbolize?
options: The approach of a powerful military force
The sound of a great flood
questions.correctAnswer: The approach of a powerful military force
questions.explanation: The verse uses auditory imagery of horses and chariots to evoke the fearsome advance of an invading army, typical of Near Eastern military descriptions.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 47:4, which two cities are mentioned as losing every helper that remains?
questions.correctAnswer: Tyrus and Zidon
questions.explanation: Verse 4 specifically states that the day will come to spoil all the Philistines and cut off every helper from Tyrus and Zidon, showing the interconnected fates of these coastal cities.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 47:5, what does the phrase 'Baldness is come upon Gaza' metaphorically signify?
options: A sign of mourning and defeat
A fashion trend among the Philistines
A call to celebrate a festival
questions.correctAnswer: A sign of mourning and defeat
questions.explanation: In ancient Near Eastern culture, shaving the head was often associated with mourning, humiliation, or defeat, which is the intended metaphor in this verse.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily employed in Jeremiah 47:6 when addressing the sword of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Personification
questions.explanation: The sword is personified as if it can be commanded to put itself into its scabbard and rest, attributing human characteristics to an object.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 47:7 explains that the sword of the LORD can be quiet because it has completed its charge against Ashkelon.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:7 indicates the sword cannot be quiet because the LORD has given it a charge against Ashkelon, meaning its work is ongoing.

questions.question: The phrase 'waters rise up out of the north' in Jeremiah 47:2 can be seen as an allusion to which other prophetic imagery of invading forces?
options: Ezekiel’s vision of Gog from the north
questions.correctAnswer: Ezekiel’s vision of Gog from the north
questions.explanation: Both Jeremiah and Ezekiel use the motif of forces coming from the north as a symbol of invading armies sent by God for judgment.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern political reality is reflected in Jeremiah 47:4’s reference to Caphtor?
options: The Philistines’ origin from Caphtor, often identified with Crete
questions.correctAnswer: The Philistines’ origin from Caphtor, often identified with Crete
questions.explanation: Caphtor is traditionally linked to the Philistine homeland, reflecting historical and ethnic context relevant to this prophecy.

questions.question: What is the significance of the repeated mention of cities like Gaza and Ashkelon in Jeremiah 47:5 and 47:7?
options: They illustrate the targeted destruction of Philistine strongholds
They are examples of cities spared by the prophecy
They represent the northern kingdom of Israel
They are symbolic names for Babylonian provinces
questions.correctAnswer: They illustrate the targeted destruction of Philistine strongholds
questions.explanation: These cities are prominent Philistine centers, and their mention emphasizes the comprehensive nature of the divine judgment.

questions.question: How does the 'overflowing flood' imagery in Jeremiah 47:2 function typologically within biblical prophecy?
options: It typifies divine judgment as an unstoppable natural force
It typifies God’s blessing and renewal
It represents the Holy Spirit’s movement
questions.correctAnswer: It typifies divine judgment as an unstoppable natural force
questions.explanation: Floods often symbolize overwhelming divine judgment in the Hebrew Bible, consistent with this passage’s theme of destruction.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the authorial intent behind Jeremiah 47’s focus on the Philistines and their cities?
options: To warn of the consequences of opposing God's plan and to show that no nation is beyond judgment
To praise the Philistines for their faithfulness
To predict the rise of a Philistine kingdom
To describe the building of a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: To warn of the consequences of opposing God's plan and to show that no nation is beyond judgment
questions.explanation: The chapter serves as a prophetic indictment aimed at the Philistines, emphasizing God's sovereign judgment over all nations.

questions.question: In the context of Jeremiah 47, the 'sword of the LORD' is best understood as a symbol for what?
options: God’s instrument of judgment and war
A literal sword belonging to Jeremiah
A symbol of peace and reconciliation
A ritual object used in worship
questions.correctAnswer: God’s instrument of judgment and war
questions.explanation: The sword metaphorically represents God's power to bring destruction and execute judgment on nations.

questions.question: What does the lament 'How long wilt thou cut thyself?' in Jeremiah 47:5 allude to in ancient Near Eastern mourning customs?
options: Self-inflicted wounds as a sign of grief
A ritual dance to celebrate victory
A practice of anointing with oil
questions.correctAnswer: Self-inflicted wounds as a sign of grief
questions.explanation: Cutting oneself was a common expression of mourning and distress, highlighting the Philistines' despair.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 47 portrays the Philistines as invincible and beyond the reach of divine judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The entire chapter prophesies the downfall and spoiling of the Philistines, showing they are subject to God's judgment.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 47 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 47 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 47:2, from which direction does the overflowing flood rise up that will overflow the land?
questions.correctAnswer: North
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:2 explicitly states that 'waters rise up out of the north' as an overflowing flood. This imagery of judgment from the north is also seen in Ezekiel 38:15 and Daniel 11:40, emphasizing God's sovereign control over nations. The flood metaphor aligns with God's judgment in Genesis 7:11 and Revelation 12:15.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 47:4, what reason is given for the LORD spoiling the Philistines and cutting off helpers from Tyre and Sidon?
options: Because of their idolatry and rebellion
Because of the day that cometh to spoil all the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the day that cometh to spoil all the Philistines
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:4 states the reason as 'because of the day that cometh to spoil all the Philistines.' This reflects God's sovereign judgment on nations opposing His covenant people, consistent with Isaiah 13:6-9 and Amos 1:6-8 where God judges nations for their sins. The theme of divine judgment for rebellion is consistent throughout Scripture (Romans 1:18, Revelation 18:6).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'sword of the LORD' mentioned in Jeremiah 47:6?
options: A symbol of divine judgment and wrath
A sign of peace and restoration
questions.correctAnswer: A symbol of divine judgment and wrath
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:6 refers to the 'sword of the LORD' as an instrument of judgment. This metaphor appears throughout Scripture as God's means of executing justice (Isaiah 34:5, Ezekiel 21:3, Hebrews 4:12). The sword represents God's holy and righteous wrath against sin, not merely human violence, highlighting His sovereignty over nations (Revelation 19:15).

questions.question: In Jeremiah 47:3, what prevents the fathers from looking back to their children?
questions.correctAnswer: Feebleness of hands
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:3 explains that 'the fathers shall not look back to their children for feebleness of hands,' indicating weakness and inability to protect or comfort their offspring amidst judgment. This reflects human frailty under divine judgment, paralleling Lamentations 2:21 and Ezekiel 12:22, emphasizing the hopelessness of those who face God's wrath.

questions.question: Which cities are specifically mentioned as being affected by judgment in Jeremiah 47?
questions.correctAnswer: Gaza, Ashkelon, Tyre, Sidon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:4-5 and 47:7 mention Gaza, Ashkelon, Tyre, and Sidon as recipients of divine judgment. These cities were prominent Philistine and Phoenician centers, reflecting God's sovereignty over all nations (Psalm 2:1-4, Isaiah 23:1-18). The judgment on these cities prefigures God's ultimate triumph over all worldly powers (Revelation 18:2-3).

questions.question: What phrase in Jeremiah 47:5 symbolizes mourning and repentance among the people of Gaza?
questions.correctAnswer: Baldness is come upon Gaza
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 47:5, 'Baldness is come upon Gaza' is a metaphor for mourning and repentance, as shaving the head was a sign of grief in ancient Israel (2 Samuel 19:24, Isaiah 15:2). This shows the depth of sorrow over impending judgment, consistent with biblical expressions of lament (Job 1:20, Ezekiel 7:18).

questions.question: Jeremiah 47:7 states that the LORD has appointed the sword against which location?
questions.correctAnswer: Ashkelon and the sea shore
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:7 declares that God has charged the sword against 'Ashkelon and against the sea shore.' This highlights God's active role in directing judgment on specific regions. This divine appointment aligns with God's sovereign control over nations (Psalm 110:5, Isaiah 10:5-6), showing His authority over history.

questions.question: What is the theological implication of 'the men shall cry, and all the inhabitants of the land shall howl' in Jeremiah 47:2?
options: It symbolizes the universal sorrow caused by God's judgment
It indicates a call to worship
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the universal sorrow caused by God's judgment
questions.explanation: The phrase in Jeremiah 47:2 conveys the profound grief and despair that accompany God's judgment. This universal sorrow echoes prophetic warnings in Joel 1:5 and Zephaniah 1:14-16, illustrating the seriousness of sin and the consequences ordained by God's holiness (Romans 1:18).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 47:1, when did the prophecy against the Philistines come to Jeremiah?
questions.correctAnswer: Before Pharaoh smote Gaza
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:1 explicitly states that the word came 'before that Pharaoh smote Gaza,' indicating the timing of the prophecy. This situates the prophecy historically and shows God's foreknowledge and sovereignty over events (Isaiah 46:10, Psalm 33:11).

questions.question: What does the 'overflowing flood' in Jeremiah 47:2 most likely represent in a theological sense?
options: A symbol of blessing and renewal
questions.correctAnswer: God’s impending judgment and wrath
questions.explanation: The 'overflowing flood' in Jeremiah 47:2 is a metaphor for God's judgment sweeping over the land, a common biblical motif (Psalm 29:10, Isaiah 59:19, Revelation 12:15). It represents the unstoppable nature of divine justice against sin.

questions.question: Jeremiah 47:4 mentions the remnant of the country of Caphtor. Who were the Caphtorim identified as in biblical tradition?
options: A people associated with the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: A people associated with the Philistines
questions.explanation: Caphtor is traditionally identified as the origin of the Philistines (Amos 9:7, Deuteronomy 2:23). Jeremiah 47:4 references the remnant of Caphtor, highlighting the judgment upon the descendants of this people. This affirms God's sovereignty over all peoples (Acts 17:26).

questions.question: In Jeremiah 47:6, what is the sword of the LORD commanded to do?
options: Put up into its scabbard, rest, and be still
Cut off the enemies of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Put up into its scabbard, rest, and be still
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:6 asks how long the sword of the LORD will not be quiet and commands it to 'put up thyself into thy scabbard, rest, and be still.' This reflects God's sovereign control over judgment timing (Ecclesiastes 3:1, Revelation 8:1), emphasizing that God alone determines when judgment begins and ends.

questions.question: What do the 'stamping of the hoofs,' 'rushing of chariots,' and 'rumbling of wheels' in Jeremiah 47:3 symbolize?
options: The coming of an invading army executing God's judgment
The celebration of a victory festival
The arrival of messengers bringing peace
The sounds of a natural disaster
questions.correctAnswer: The coming of an invading army executing God's judgment
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:3 uses the imagery of horses' hoofs, chariots, and wheels to depict a powerful military force sent by God to execute judgment. Similar imagery occurs in Joel 2:4 and Nahum 2:3, symbolizing God's use of earthly powers to accomplish His divine purposes (Romans 13:4).

questions.question: Which doctrinal theme is illustrated by God's sovereign appointment of judgment against Ashkelon and the seashore in Jeremiah 47:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine sovereignty over nations
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:7 expresses God's sovereign choice to bring judgment upon Ashkelon and the seashore. This emphasizes God's control over history and nations, a key biblical doctrine found in Psalm 22:28, Daniel 4:35, and Romans 8:28, highlighting that God governs all to fulfill His purposes.

questions.question: What does the lament 'how long wilt thou cut thyself?' in Jeremiah 47:5 imply about the Philistines' response to judgment?
options: A call to cease self-inflicted mourning and repent
A demand for revenge against enemies
A question about the length of war
An expression of joy for victory
questions.correctAnswer: A call to cease self-inflicted mourning and repent
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 47:5's question 'how long wilt thou cut thyself?' refers to the Philistines' mourning practices, possibly self-harm as a sign of grief. The rhetorical question challenges the futility of their sorrow without repentance, similar to Jeremiah 16:6 and Joel 2:13, underscoring repentance as necessary before God.
